   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest
   .
   # Respiratory failure.  He was originally intubated in setting of
   arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT
   chest and has had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear
   whether he truly has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
   negative to date.
   - Continue with ventilation.  Will likely not be able to think of
   extubation until patient
s mental status improves.
   - Cannot have CVVH today because of  HD catheter malfunction.  Renal
   notified and feel this is fine for today and they will reassess
   tomorrow.
   - Continue to do daily RSBI / SBT
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  It has recently been difficult
   to assess his mental status because he is so agitated when we lighten
   sedation.  His MRI, though severely limited by motion artifact, did not
   show any signs of acute ischemia.  His EEG reads show possible seizure
   activity.
   - We will try to sedate him as much as possible with just propofol and
   small amounts of fentanyl; he is not tolerating the lowering of
   fentanyl well
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - F/u Neurology recs.
   - start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
    .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   .
   # Fever: Patient
s fever curve is improving now with lines removed
   (some low grade fevers overnight)  Dialysis line is growing
   micrococcus.
   - ID believes cefepime will suffice for treatment.  As this was an
   infected line/bacteremia, we should cover with 14 days of adequate
   antibiotics.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid pending ID input.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Restarted back on
   CVVH after getting new lines placed, yesterday many liters negative.
   Don't feel that we need to be as aggressive with fluid removal as he is
   about 14L negative through LOS.   Will have to await a new line before
   proceeding with dialysis
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Not clinically significant at this point.
   - Restart Calcitriol
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   .
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 7d course but will continue due
   to persistent fevers.
   .
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy,
   but may be some seizure activity.  Recommended starting Keppra when
   Propofol off
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease
   - continue to monitor.
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), and chronic renal failure who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He recently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and is currently in the ICU. The patient has several medical complications that require close monitoring and management.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated due to possible hypoxia during the arrest. There is a question of pneumonia (PNA) on the chest CT, but the cultures are negative to date. Continuous ventilation is ongoing, and extubation may not be considered until the patient's mental status improves.

2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered following the PEA arrest. Agitation and continuous gagging are observed when lightening sedation. An MRI did not show signs of acute ischemia, but EEG readings show possible seizure activity. Propofol and small amounts of fentanyl will be used to sedate the patient. Lidocaine oral spray will be tried to help tolerate the endotracheal tube. Neurology recommendations will be followed, and Keppra will be started when off propofol.

3. Labile Blood Pressures: The patient experiences intermittent hypotension possibly due to hypovolemia or an infectious source, as well as intermittent hypertension. Labetalol will be given if hypertensive,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who presented with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He was admitted to the ICU and intubated due to a possible hypoxic event during cardiac arrest. The patient's respiratory status declined when moved back onto pressure support ventilation, and there are questions about pneumonia on the chest CT and CXRs showing left lower lobe atelectasis versus infiltrate. The patient's mental status has been altered since the cardiac arrest, and he is agitated when sedation is lightened. His MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia, but his EEG shows possible seizure activity. 

The patient has labile blood pressures, with intermittent hypotension and hypertension, for which he was given labetalol. The fever curve is improving after removing infected lines, and the dialysis line is growing micrococcus. The ID believes cefepime will be sufficient for treatment. The patient's acute-on-chronic renal failure is unclear, but he will likely not regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis. He has been restarted on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) after getting new lines placed. 

The patient's elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary due to renal failure and not clinically significant at this point. He should restart calcitriol. The patient also has right upper extremity swelling, which is

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest
   .
   # Respiratory failure.  He was originally intubated in setting of
   arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT
   chest and has had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear
   whether he truly has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
   negative to date.
   - Continue with ventilation.  Will likely not be able to think of
   extubation until patient
s mental status improves.
   - Cannot have CVVH today because of  HD catheter malfunction.  Renal
   notified and feel this is fine for today and they will reassess
   tomorrow.
   - Continue to do daily RSBI / SBT
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  It has recently been difficult
   to assess his mental status because he is so agitated when we lighten
   sedation.  His MRI, though severely limited by motion artifact, did not
   show any signs of acute ischemia.  His EEG reads show possible seizure
   activity.
   - We will try to sedate him as much as possible with just propofol and
   small amounts of fentanyl; he is not tolerating the lowering of
   fentanyl well
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - F/u Neurology recs.
   - start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
    .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   .
   # Fever: Patient
s fever curve is improving now with lines removed
   (some low grade fevers overnight)  Dialysis line is growing
   micrococcus.
   - ID believes cefepime will suffice for treatment.  As this was an
   infected line/bacteremia, we should cover with 14 days of adequate
   antibiotics.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid pending ID input.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Restarted back on
   CVVH after getting new lines placed, yesterday many liters negative.
   Don't feel that we need to be as aggressive with fluid removal as he is
   about 14L negative through LOS.   Will have to await a new line before
   proceeding with dialysis
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Not clinically significant at this point.
   - Restart Calcitriol
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   .
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 7d course but will continue due
   to persistent fevers.
   .

   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy,
   but may be some seizure activity.  Recommended starting Keppra when
   Propofol off

   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old man who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure. He experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and required resuscitation. The patient has a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is on chronic hemodialysis. He also has diabetes mellitus type II and hypertension.

Upon admission, the patient was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He was sedated with propofol and received fentanyl for pain management. The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, with periods of agitation and delirium. He has copious oral secretions, which may require additional interventions.

The patient's blood pressure has been labile, with episodes of hypotension and hypertension. Labetalol was initially used to control blood pressure, but it was stopped due to low blood pressures. The patient's fever curve has improved since removing the infected lines.

Renal function tests indicate acute on chronic renal failure. The etiology of acute renal failure is unclear, but it is unlikely that the patient will regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis. The patient is currently undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) with CVVH.

Other issues include a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to cefepime. The patient is still on cefepime to cover this infection. Additionally, there are concerns about seizure

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and is currently in the ICU. The patient has multiple medical conditions, including hypertension (HTN), diabetes mellitus (DM), and a history of chronic renal failure treated with continuous renal replacement therapy (CRT). He has been intubated due to respiratory failure, and his mental status is altered post-PEA arrest. The patient's blood pressures are labile, and he has been experiencing intermittent hypotension and hypertension. He also has a fever, which has improved with the removal of infected lines. The patient's renal function is acute on chronic, and he is undergoing continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH). He has an elevated parathyroid hormone level, indicating secondary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure. The patient also has right upper extremity swelling, likely due to a thrombosed/stenosed brachio-cephalic vein. He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is sensitive to cefepime. There is also a suspicion of seizure activity or myoclonus, which is being evaluated further. The patient's glucose control is maintained with a sliding scale insulin. His anemia is chronic and stable, possibly

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest
   .
   # Respiratory failure.  Respiratory status declined last night as we
   was moved back onto CMV/Assist from pressure support.  He was
   originally intubated in setting of arrest with possible hypoxia
   beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has had CXR's with
   LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly has PNA or
   not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to date.
   - Continue with pressure support ventilation.  Will likely not be able
   to think of extubation until patient
s mental status improves.
   - Continue continuous dialysis to remove any excess fluid
   - Should do daily RSBI / SBT today
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  It has recently been difficult
   to assess his mental status because he is so agitated when we lighten
   sedation.  His MRI, though severely limited by motion artifact, did not
   show any signs of acute ischemia.  His EEG reads show possible seizure
   activity.
   - We will try to sedate him as much as possible with just propofol and
   small amounts of fentanyl; he is not tolerating the lowering of
   fentanyl well
   - repeat an exam this afternoon off of propofol
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - F/u Neurology recs.
   - start  Keppra when off propofol
    .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   .
   # Fever: Patient
s fever curve is improving now with lines removed
   (some low grade fevers overnight)  Dialysis line is growing
   micrococcus.
   - ID believes cefepime will suffice for treatment.  As this was an
   infected line/bacteremia, we should cover with 14 days of adequate
   antibiotics.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid pending ID input.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Restarted back on
   CVVH after getting new lines placed, yesterday many liters negative.
   Don't feel that we need to be as aggressive with fluid removal as he is
   about 14L negative through LOS.  Femoral dialysis port was replaced
   last night by IR
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Not clinically significant at this point.
   - Restart Calcitriol
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought to be unlikely. When pt had PICC placed yesterday
   found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   .
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 7d course but will continue due
   to persistent fevers.
   .
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy.
   - f/u EEG results
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease
   - continue to monitor.
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who has been admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He recently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and has been intubated.

The patient's respiratory status has declined, and he is currently on pressure support ventilation. There are concerns about possible pneumonia, but chest X-rays have shown left lower lobe atelectasis versus infiltrate, and bronchoscopy has been unrevealing. The patient is also on continuous dialysis to remove excess fluid.

The patient's mental status is altered post-PEA arrest, and he is agitated when sedation is lightened. An MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia, but EEGs show possible seizure activity. Propofol and fentanyl sedation will be continued, and a repeat neurological examination will be done today.

The patient has labile blood pressures, which may be due to hypovolemia or an infectious source. Labetalol will be given if the patient is hypertensive, and small fluid boluses will be given if hypotensive. If CVVH is not working and the patient has metabolic acidosis, sodium bicarb boluses may be considered.

The patient's fever curve is improving now that lines have been removed. The dialysis line is growing Micrococcus species, and ID believes cefepime will suffice for

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure. He subsequently experienced a cardiac arrest and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was originally intubated in the setting of arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand. There is ongoing debate regarding pneumonia on CT chest and has had chest X-rays showing left lower lobe atelectasis versus infiltrate. It is unclear whether he truly has pneumonia or not. A bronchoscopic evaluation was unrevealing, and cultures have been negative to date.

2. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is fluctuating, making it difficult to assess his level of consciousness. He is agitated when sedation is lightened, which limits the ability to perform spontaneous breathing trials (SBT). There are plans to continue daily trials of stopping sedation and measuring respiratory system compliance (RSBI) / SBT.

3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) is superimposed on his pre-existing ESRD. The etiology of ARF is unclear, but it is unlikely that he will regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis. He has been restarted on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) after getting new lines placed. However, there have been problems

 RENAL FAILURE, END STAGE (END STAGE RENAL DISEASE, ESRD)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
   Active issues at this point:
   # Respiratory failure.  He was originally intubated in setting of
   arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT
   chest and has had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear
   whether he truly has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
   negative to date.
   - Continues mechanically ventilated due to mental status and it is
   unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off sedation
   exams have been less purposeful recently, after initial signs of
   progress and following commands.
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - Will have to start thinking about trach/PEG if family wants to
   continue support.
   - Will need to have repeat family meeting about goals of care, but will
   have to touch base with Neurology about his chances of recovery first,
   given most recent exams
   - Daily off sedation exams, RSBI
s, SBT
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  His MRI, though severely
   limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute ischemia.
   Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   - Had been trying to wean the Fentanyl and sedate more with Propofol,
   but has not tolerated this very well and still on substantial amts of
   Fentanyl
   - Continue to try Lidocaine oral spray to see if he can tolerate the
   ETT tube
   - Start  Keppra when off propofol
   - consider haldol instead of fentanyl in the future
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of ARF
   unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful.
   - No need for urgent HD/CVVH per renal
   - Will need to go to IR on Monday for replacement of his line, then
   restart CVVH afterwards.
   - continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In
   the meantime, if he is hypotensive we should give small fluid boluses
   while running CVVH even.
   - Labetolol gtt if hypertensive
   - If hypotensive, give small fluid boluses.  If CVVH is not working and
   patient still has metabolic acidosis, consider boluses with sodium
   bicarb.
   # Fever: Pt still with some low grade fevers, has been on long course
   of Cefepime and most recently Linezolid added for past 6 days. These
   were initially treating UTI with Pseudomonas. Now, he has grown out
   Micrococcus from
 catheter tips from CVL
s that were pulled the other
   day. ID has said that Cefipime will suffice for this Micrococcus.
   - Continue Cefepime and Linezolid for 14d course. Today is day 10 of
   Cefepime and day 6 of Linezolid
   - Would clarify the exact time course for these two ABx
 14d from when
   Micrococcus was isolated?
   # HypoNa: Possibly volume deplete as he is about 14L negative through
   LOS. Will give small 250cc bolus today and f/u electrolytes later
   today.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic.
   - F/u with renal about electrolytes
   Other stable issues:
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile
   #  UTI. Borderline UA. Culture positive for Pseudomonas of 2
   morphologies.  Sensitive to Zosyn and cefepime.
   - Continue Cefepime.  Has now completed 10d course but will continue
   due to persistent fevers.
   # ?Seizure activity vs. myoclonus. Another 20 minute EEG was done this
   morning  Neuro has said that at this point it is likely encephalopathy,
   but may be some seizure activity.  Recommended starting Keppra when
   Propofol off
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease
   - continue to monitor.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and R fem HD line with VIP
   port placed [**11-23**]
 will need to have R fem HD line replaced

The patient was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure and subsequently experienced a cardiac arrest. 

The active issues at this point include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated due to mental status and it is unclear if his mental status will improve. He also has copious secretions, which is concerning for aspiration if he were to be weaned from the ventilator.
2. Altered mental status post-PEA arrest: The patient's MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia, but he has been agitated upon weaning of sedation. Sedation has been restarted with Propofol.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The etiology of ARF is unclear, but the patient's renal function is unlikely to improve enough to be free of dialysis. The patient's CVVH has not been functioning well, and the HD line needs to be replaced.
4. Labile blood pressures: The patient has intermittent hypotension due to either hypovolemia or an infectious source, and hypertension for which he was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG. Tighter control of blood pressure is needed.

The patient has a history of renal transplant and is currently experiencing acute respiratory failure, altered mental status, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and a recent cardiac arrest. The patient's neurologic exam has shown significant improvement, but he has been more delirious for the past few days.

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume set at 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), chronic renal failure, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure. The patient experienced a cardiac arrest and is now vent-dependent due to mental status changes.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient continues to be mechanically ventilated due to mental status and copious secretions, which increases the risk of aspiration.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex. Weaning of sedation has shown agitation, and there is a concern for potential seizure activity.
3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient needs to have his femoral hemodialysis (HD) line replaced today, and CVVH is not functioning well. He may require stress dose prednisone if HD unstable.
4. Labile blood pressures: The patient has intermittent hypotension due to hypovolemia or an infectious source, as well as hypertension. Close monitoring and management are necessary.
5. Fever: The patient continues to have low-grade temperatures despite being on long courses of antibiotics (Cefepime and Linezolid). The source of infection needs further investigation.
6. HypoNa: The patient's sodium levels are low due to lipemia. Small fluid boluses will be given to address this issue.
7. Elevated PTH: The patient's parathyroid hormone level is elevated likely secondary or tertiary due to renal failure. Renal follow-up is recommended.
8. RUE swelling: The patient has swelling in the right upper extremity, which may be related to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein. Plasty is required prior to PICC removal.
9. UTI: The patient has a culture-positive urinary tract infection with Pseudomonas, sensitive to Zosyn and Cefepime. Continuing Cefepime is recommended.
10. Seizure activity vs. myoclonus: An EEG was done to differentiate between seizures and myoclonus. Keppra may be started when Propofol is off.
11. DM type II: The patient's blood sugar levels are well-controlled with a sliding scale only.
12. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, possibly related to renal disease or ACD.

These potential complications should be closely monitored and managed appropriately to ensure the patient's well-being.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), and chronic renal failure. He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure and subsequently experienced a cardiac arrest. The patient is now dependent on mechanical ventilation due to mental status changes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient continues to be mechanically ventilated due to mental status changes and the risk of aspiration. There is a need for further evaluation and potential tracheostomy if the patient's mental status does not improve.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has not improved despite weaning off sedation, indicating a potential ongoing neurological issue. Further assessment by neurology is recommended to determine the chances of recovery.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is severely compromised, and the etiology of acute renal failure is unclear. It is unlikely that he will regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.
4. Fever: Despite being on antibiotics, the patient continues to have low-grade fevers. The source of infection is still unclear, and additional testing is required to identify the cause.
5. Hypotension and Hypertension: The patient experiences intermittent hypotension and hypertension, which may be due to hypovolemia or an infectious source. Close monitoring and adjustment of fluid and medication therapy are necessary.
6. Catheter-Related Infection: The patient had a catheter tip culture positive for Micrococcus, but it is being treated with Cefepime.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has a negative fluid balance and may have hypoNa. Small fluid boluses and electrolyte monitoring are recommended.
8. Hypercalcemia and Hyperphosphatemia: The patient has elevated PTH levels secondary to renal failure. Renal consultation is needed for further management.
9. RUE Swelling: The patient has swelling in the right upper extremity, possibly due to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein. Vascular intervention may be required.
10. UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection with Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to Cefepime. Continuing the antibiotic therapy is necessary.
11. Seizure Activity vs. Myoclonus: The patient may be experiencing seizure activity or myoclonus. An EEG was performed, and the neurology team is evaluating the results.

These potential medical complications require close monitoring and appropriate management to optimize the patient's health outcomes.

He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure and subsequently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. 

The patient is currently mechanically ventilated due to mental status and the uncertainty of his ability to wean off sedation. There are concerns about potential pneumonia (PNA) and the need for a tracheostomy/peg tube if the family decides to continue life support. 

The patient's altered mental status is attributed to the PEA arrest, and his brain MRI did not show signs of acute ischemia. Weaning of sedation has shown agitation, and he has been switched from propofol to versed due to hypertriglyceridemia.

The patient is experiencing labile blood pressures, intermittent hypotension, and hypertension. The cause of hypotension is unclear, with possibilities including hypovolemia or an infectious source. Hypertension is being managed with labetalol.

There are ongoing issues with fever, and the patient is still on cefepime and linezolid. These medications were initially prescribed to treat a urinary tract infection (UTI) with Pseudomonas, but the recent growth of Micrococcus from catheter tips suggests a possible catheter-related bloodstream infection. Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of renal transplant admitted for worsening chronic renal failure. He experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest during the insertion of a hemodialysis line and had a right subclavian hemodialysis line placed over a wire, which became clogged and not functioning properly. The patient also has high triglycerides, propofol-related diarrhea, and fevers.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius (100.7 degrees Fahrenheit), a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 119/57 mmHg to 189/107 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation level of 100%. The patient's weight has decreased from 110 kg at admission to 83.5 kg currently.

The patient is receiving various medications, including fentanyl, midazolam, heparin sodium, famotidine, prednisone, chlorhexidine, Pepcid, cellcept, cefepime, albuterol/atrovent, and vitamin D.

The patient's fluid balance shows an intake of 3,071 mL with outputs of 485 mL through the gastrointestinal tract and 2,586 mL through intravenous fluids. The patient's blood products show a total output of 959 mL.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, and altered mental status. He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and experienced a post-cardiac arrest (PEA) arrest. The patient is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.

Active issues at this point include respiratory failure, altered mental status, and acute on chronic renal failure. The patient has been intubated due to possible hypoxia and potential pneumonia (PNA), which is still unclear. He has been on acetaminophen and cefepime for most of his MICU course. Recently, he was tried on pressure support and tolerated it well.

The patient's altered mental status post-PEA arrest is a concern. He has intact brainstem reflexes but shows signs of agitation and lack of progress. An MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia, but continuous EEG monitoring was restarted due to a staring spell witnessed yesterday. The neuro team plans to start keppra if there are EEG changes and will give a trial of Haldol today to see if there is any improvement.

In terms of renal failure, the patient has acute on chronic renal failure, likely secondary to his ESRD. The etiology of ARF is unclear, but it is unlikely that he will regain enough renal function to be

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and cardiac arrest. The patient is currently dependent on mechanical ventilation due to mental status changes.

Active issues at this point include respiratory failure, altered mental status, renal failure, and possible seizure activity. The patient has been experiencing copious secretions, which is concerning for aspiration if he were to be weaned from the ventilator. The altered mental status may be a result of the recent cardiac arrest, and it is unclear if his mental status will improve given that his off sedation exams have been less purposeful recently.

The patient also has labile blood pressures, intermittent hypotension, and hypertension. There is a possibility of an infectious source causing the hypotension. The patient is currently on a long course of antibiotics including cefepime and linezolid. The fever could be due to an ongoing infection, and the patient has recently grown Micrococcus from catheter tips, which is being treated with cefepime.

Other stable issues include chronic anemia, hypoNa, and elevated PTH levels secondary to renal failure. The patient has RUE swelling, possibly related to a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein, and a urinary tract infection (UTI) with culture positive for Pseudomonas.

Overall, the

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of failed renal transplant and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis (HD). He experienced a cardiac arrest and respiratory failure. The patient has allergies to vancomycin and has received cefipime and linezolid as antibiotics. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.4C (99.3F), heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 91/45 mmHg to 137/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. 

The patient is receiving multiple medications including fentanyl, midazolam, famotidine, heparin sodium, prednisone, insulin, cell cept, albuterol, epo, and others. 

Fluid balance shows a total input of 2,524 mL and a total output of 1,442 mL. 

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The ABG results indicate a pH of 7.27, PaCO2 of 55 mmHg, HCO3- of 22 mEq/L, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

Physical examination reveals generalized edema in both lower extremities and unresponsiveness with no assessment of movement or tone. 

Laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), potassium, and glucose. The white blood cell count is slightly elevated, while hemoglobin and platelet levels are within normal ranges. Other lab values such as liver enzymes, electrolytes, and cardiac markers are also provided. 

The patient has a history of diarrhea, altered mental status (not delirium), renal failure (ESRD), acute respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest. 

The plan includes starting haloperidol to control agitation, replacing the dialysis line, discussing tracheostomy with the family, and continuing ICU care. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and further deterioration of renal function.

s negative to

   pressure support and tolerating well.
   - At this point, most importantly need to speak with family and discuss
   trach/PEG and moving towards rehab as he doesn
t appear to be making
   great strides in terms of his mental status or his respiratory status.
   - His agitation could be in part due to the ETT and it
s reasonable to
   to think getting it out could be beneficial
 Trach talk with family
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700.
   - Neuro has been following and they have put him back on continuous EEG
   due to a staring spell that they witnessed yesterday
   - Start  Keppra if having EEG changes
   - Will give a trial of Haldol today to see if any improvement.

   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will

   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and have been
   unsuccessful. Needs to have femoral HD line replaced today.

   CVVH afterwards.

   out Micrococcus from
 catheter tips from CVL

    # Labile blood pressures: Pt having intermittent hypotension due to
   either hypovolemia vs infectious source, and hypertension for which he
   was getting Labetalol 400mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **].  Next time he is hypertensive we
   will try a labetalol drip to have tighter control with a short-acting
   medication that can be stopped when we are trying to remove fluid.  In

epileptiform
   activity
 according to Neuro. He was not ever started on AED

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and subsequently experienced a cardiac arrest (PEA). The patient is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes. Active issues include respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal failure, fever, and labile blood pressures. Other less active/stable issues include anemia, hypoNa, endocrine abnormalities, and right upper extremity swelling. The patient has been on a prolonged course of antibiotics and has grown Micrococcus from central line tips, but ID has stated that cefepime will suffice for this organism. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, as he is ventilator-dependent and has had episodes of LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate. The need for tracheostomy and weaning from the ventilator should be discussed with the family.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has not improved despite previous efforts to wean sedation. Continuous EEG monitoring has been restarted due to a staring spell witnessed by neurology. Additional trials of antipsychotic medications may be considered.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is likely to remain impaired, and he may require ongoing dialysis. The placement of a

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with dyspnea, acute renal failure (ARF), and cardiac arrest. Currently, he is ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status.

The patient's active issues include respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal failure, and fever. The respiratory failure is likely due to possible hypoxia during cardiac arrest and subsequent ventilator dependence. The altered mental status may be a result of the PEA arrest, and further evaluation with continuous EEG monitoring is ongoing.

The patient's acute on chronic renal failure is likely secondary to the ESRD, and the etiology of ARF is unclear. CVVH has been initiated, but it is not functioning well. The patient needs to have a femoral HD line replaced today for better dialysis.

The fever is low-grade and may be due to a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Pseudomonas, which has been treated with cefepime. However, recently Micrococcus has grown from the catheter tips of the central venous line (CVL), but ID has stated that cefepime will suffice for this infection.

Other less active/stable issues include anemia, labile blood pressures, hypoNa, endocrine abnormalities, right upper extremity swelling, and possible seizure activity.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure. He underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and is now dependent on the ventilator due to mental status changes. The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal failure, fever, anemia, labile blood pressures, hypoNa, endocrine abnormalities, RUE swelling, and possible seizure activity.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still dependent on the ventilator due to mental status changes and agitation. There is a concern for pneumonia, and the possibility of tracheostomy placement is being considered.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has not improved despite weaning off sedation. There is a concern for continued seizures, and he has been started on Kendra (levetiracetam) for seizure prophylaxis.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is unstable, and he requires ongoing dialysis. There is a need for a reliable vascular access, and a subclavian HD line placement has been scheduled.
4. Fever: The patient has had a long course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture with Pseudomonas. Now that the culture results are back, the antibiotics may be stopped, and the fever curve will be monitored.
5. Anemia

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will
   need to discuss PEG placement with family
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: L art line, R PICC placed [**11-23**], and new L subclavian HD line
   placed [**11-30**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement. If trach and PEG placed,
   could consider moving to vent rehab.
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute respiratory failure. He had a cardiac arrest and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes. The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal failure, fever, anemia, labile blood pressures, hypoNa, endocrine abnormalities, RUE swelling, and diabetes mellitus type II.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may lead to further complications such as pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status can increase the risk of aspiration, seizures, and difficulty weaning off the ventilator.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's acute exacerbation of chronic renal failure may result in further deterioration of renal function, electrolyte imbalances, and fluid overload.
4. Fever: The presence of fever could indicate an ongoing infection, which may lead to sepsis or septic shock if not promptly identified and treated.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may contribute to fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Labile Blood Pressures: The patient's labile blood pressures can increase the risk of end-organ damage and complications associated with hypertension.

 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now vent dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Will continue today with schedule Haldol to see if any improvement in
   his mental status 5mg PO tid
   - Seroquel was also tried last night, but unsure if either the Haldol
   or the Seroquel, or increasing the Versed, has made much difference
   - F/u EKG for Haldol/Seroquel
   - Get baseline EKG for Haldol
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Had considered transfusing yesterday, will give him 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with dyspnea, acute respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury. He underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation and is now dependent on the ventilator due to altered mental status.

The patient's current issues include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated during cardiac arrest and may have had hypoxia prior to that. There is a question of pneumonia on chest CT, but the patient's bronchoscopy and cultures have been negative so far. The main hindrance to weaning from the ventilator is his agitation, thrashing around, and lack of responsiveness. There is concern for aspiration due to excessive secretions.

2. Altered mental status: The patient had a post-cardiac arrest altered mental status. His MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia. Weaning of sedation leads to agitation and thrashing. He was on Propofol but switched to Versed due to triglyceride levels of 700. Neurology has noted a staring spell that could be concerning for seizures, so continuous EEG was performed, showing epileptiform spikes but no seizure activity. Keppra was started, and the dose needs to be clarified with Neurology. Haldol and Seroquel were tried but with limited success.

3. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient underwent continuous renal

The patient is a 61-year-old male with a medical history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure and subsequently experienced a cardiac arrest. The patient is currently ventilator-dependent and has been experiencing agitation and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to the inability to wean off the ventilator. The main hindrance is his agitation and thrashing around, which can lead to potential complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or barotrauma.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be a result of the cardiac arrest or an underlying neurological condition. It is crucial to monitor for seizures and continue EEG monitoring. The patient is currently on antiepileptic medication (Keppra) and sedatives (Versed and Haldol) to manage his agitation and potential seizure activity.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is superimposed on chronic renal failure. This could be due to several factors, including hypotension, infection, or medication toxicity. CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemodialysis) has been restarted, but there have been issues with its functioning. Close monitoring of renal function and electrolyte imbalances is essential.

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and we should move towards trach.
   - First priority for today will be to coordinate IP and family for
   trach/PEG tomorrow when IP is available; need consent for procedures
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
 Will

   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI

 need new art line placed today, R PICC placed

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who presented with dyspnea, acute respiratory failure (ARF), and possible hypoxia. The patient was intubated during cardiac arrest and has been ventilator-dependent ever since. The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, hypertension, altered mental status, renal failure, and cardiac arrest.

Respiratory failure: The patient's main hindrance to weaning from the ventilator is his agitation, which could be due to the endotracheal tube (ETT). There is also concern for aspiration due to copious secretions. It is recommended to coordinate with the patient's family for a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tomorrow when the patient is available.

Altered mental status: The patient has intact brainstem reflexes but has difficulty assessing his cortex. The MRI did not show any signs of acute ischemia. Weaning of sedation consistently shows agitation, and there have been recent episodes of thrashing around, not following commands, and not making progress. Propofol was changed to versed due to triglyceride levels of 700. The neurologist noted a staring spell that was concerning for continued seizures, so continuous EEG was performed, showing epileptiform spikes but no outright seizure activity. It is recommended to continue on Fentanyl as is, increase haldol to 10mg tid, and slowly upt

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis who experienced cardiac arrest and respiratory failure. He is currently in the ICU and requires increased sedation due to agitation overnight. The patient has a history of hypertension, diarrhea, altered mental status, renal failure, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest. He is on multiple medications including calcium gluconate, fentanyl, midazolam, KCl, and others. The patient's vital signs are within normal range, but he has right and left lower extremity edema. His laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, potassium, and glucose, while other values are within normal range. The patient's respiratory support includes being on a ventilator with a tidal volume set at 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, PEEP at 5 cmH2O, FiO2 at 40%, and SpO2 of 100%. The patient's cardiovascular system shows normal heart sounds, and peripheral pulses are not assessed. Neurologically, the patient is unresponsive and does not follow simple commands. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Seizures: The patient may be having seizure activity, and the dose of keppra is being uptitrated.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's agitation is a major limitation on weaning from mechanical ventilation.

- He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and subsequently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest.
- The patient is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status and has been sedated.
- He has been experiencing respiratory failure, with difficulty weaning from the ventilator due to agitation and risk of aspiration.
- The patient's altered mental status post-PEA arrest has shown some improvement but with recent regression, including a staring spell that was concerning for seizures.
- He has been on continuous EEG monitoring, and epileptiform spikes have been observed without outright seizure activity.
- The patient's acute on chronic renal failure is ongoing, with unclear etiology of ARF. He is unlikely to regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.
- He has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and has had issues with the functioning of his renal access lines.
- The patient has had a long course of antibiotics for a positive urine culture with Pseudomonas and recently developed purulent appearing central venous lines (CVLs) that were removed and grew Micrococcus.
- He has been receiving a combination of Cefepime and Linezolid for his infections.

   The ET tube tip is 6 cm above the carina. The left subclavian line tip
   is at

   Assessment and Plan
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
    Active issues at this point:
   .
    # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s negative to
   date.  Main hindrance to weaning from vent is his agitation, whenever
   his sedation is weaning he thrashes around, isn
t responsive, looks
   very uncomfortable, drools a lot. This agitation could be in large part
   due to his ETT and trach placement should help with this.
   - IP for trach and PEG--> need to call to assure is on schedule
   - He is also having copious secretions which is concerning for
   aspiration if he were to be weaned from the vent
   - He is very agitated and difficult to be weaned from the vent
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient obviously has intact
   brainstem reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI,
   though severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of
   acute ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation.
   He was making some strides towards improvement last week, with
   following commands and responding to the environment, but most recently
   he has just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is
   weaned, not following commands, not tracking across the room, not
   making progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of
   triglycerides of 700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell
   that was concerning for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG
   for a while, with epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure
   activity. They recommended a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an
   extra 250 after HD.
   - He is currently written for Keppra 250mg IV q12, will need to clarify
   dose with Neuro
   - Will slowly uptitrate his Versed gtt. Continue on Fentanyl as is.
   - Increase haldol to 10mg tid
   - F/u EKG done today because of Haldol/Seroquel use
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully since yesterday.
   - Continue CVVH per renal recommendations.
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - Have stopped calcitriol and increased aluminum hydroxide per renal
   recs
   - Renal is following
   .
   # Fever: Continued low-grade temps, although none most recently. Has
   had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2 wks ago with
   Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for purulent
   appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the CVL
   grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should have
   covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.
   - Continue off ABx for now, watch fever curve.
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.
   - Will start Epogen with HD
   - Transfuse 1U PRBC's today
   .
    # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, and has
   started on scheduled Labetalol.
   - Keep watching pressures, and go up on Labetalol as necessary.
   - If hypoTN returns, stop Labetalol and consider small boluses in
   context of getting CVVH.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but not recently.
   Continue to watch lytes qday.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose well-controlled now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - BS
s in 100
s, will continue to cover with SSI only
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who has undergone continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). He is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes. The patient's medical history includes hypertension (HTN), diabetes mellitus (DM), and chronic renal failure (CRF). He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and subsequently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. 

Active issues at this point include respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal failure, fever, anemia, labile blood pressures, hypoNa, endocrine abnormalities, right upper extremity swelling, and diabetes mellitus type II. 

The patient has been treated with various medications and interventions, including antibiotics for a positive urine culture, antiepileptic drugs due to suspected seizures, and renal replacement therapy. 

The patient's laboratory results indicate several abnormalities, including elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, high creatinine, elevated potassium, and abnormal liver function tests. 

Imaging studies have shown bilateral pleural effusions and atelectasis. 

The patient's current plan includes continuing CVVH, tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement, weaning off sedation, titrating midazolam, increasing haloperidol, and monitoring for seizures.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with respiratory failure following a cardiac arrest. He remains agitated and requires heavy sedation. The patient has a history of hypertension, anemia, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD). He is currently experiencing diarrhea and altered mental status. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.2C, heart rate of 96 bpm, blood pressure of 145/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased creatinine levels, and altered electrolyte levels. His glucose levels are within normal range.

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including hypertension, anemia, and ESRD. He is being treated with various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and renal replacement therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is the main barrier due to poor muscle strength. There is a concern for increased secretions, and a new chest X-ray may be necessary to assess any changes.

2. Altered Mental Status: The patient is on reduced doses of sedatives and has been given haloperidol to manage agitation. Monitoring for any changes in mental status is important to prevent further complications.

3. Renal Failure
