 CARDIAC ARREST
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   - Monitor patient to determine whether he develops fever
   - Monitor PO2 and respiratory status
   - Hold tube feeds for the morning
   - Consider CXR tomorrow
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Trach mask again today
   - Decreased Methadone to 5 to wean.  Continue at current dose for
   today.
   - Zyprexa PRN agitation
   .
     # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**].
   - Hypertensive today in setting of having morning dose of PO labetalol
   held.  Change parameters to hold if below SBP <120 and continue
   Labetalol 800 TID
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.  Decrease in hct today without evidence of active
   bleed.
   - Repeat Hct this afternoon.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: Infection (recent sputum with
   Micrococcus and now with positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood
   transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't received transfusions
   before this), possible drug reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP
   (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with free air under diaphragm
   (although just had PEG placed).   Currently afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - no beta-blockers
   - f/u beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR
   - Coumadin 5mg PO daily
   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD MWF
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: pending rehab placement if can wean from vent.  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 273**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] working on placement. Place PT/OT consult.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), and coronary artery disease (CAD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He is currently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the provided information include:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient had emesis during morning rounds and aspirated tube feeds. The risk for aspiration pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia is present. Monitoring the patient for signs of infection, such as fever, and holding tube feeds may be necessary.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient was originally intubated in the setting of arrest with possible hypoxia beforehand. There is a question about whether he truly has pneumonia or not. Some atelectasis or infiltrates seen on chest X-rays may need to be further evaluated.

3. Hypertension: The patient has been intermittently hypertensive, and labetalol was given. He is now persistently hypertensive. Adjusting the antihypertensive medication may be necessary.

4. Anemia: The patient has chronic and stable anemia, possibly related to renal disease or autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Further evaluation, such as repeat Hct and EPO at HD, is recommended.

5. Spiking fevers, hypotension: The patient's spiking fevers and hypotension may be due to various

   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h for now, will discuss with Neuro
   - Continue weaning sedation, as above.
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   # Anemia.  Chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis
   - HD Friday and assess need for blood products at this time.
   - EPO at HD
   - Guiac stools
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR
   - Coumadin 5mg PO daily
   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - HD MWF
   - Continue cellcept/prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD
   unstable.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Novasource Renal)
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, discontinue famotidine and instead
   start sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: pending rehab placement if can wean from vent.  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 273**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] working on placement.

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM) type II. He was admitted with dyspnea, acute renal failure (ARF), and now requires mechanical ventilation due to mental status changes. The patient has been intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive, and his blood pressure is currently well-controlled with oral labetalol. He is febrile, and his fever curve is trending down after starting Bactrim. The patient has a history of chronic anemia, which may be related to renal disease or autoimmune hemolytic anemia (ACD). He has also been diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC), and is being treated with heparin and Coumadin. The patient's renal function is acute on chronic, and he is on chronic hemodialysis (HD) three times a week. He has been started on renal replacement therapy with continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVH) but has not been functioning well. The patient's mental status has fluctuated, with periods of improved interaction and following commands, but recent agitation and thrashing around.    s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Hct stable despite 2 units pRBC: DIC and hemolysis labs negative,
   consider bleed.
   - transfuse 2 units pRBC
   - repeat PM CBC, DIC panel, hemolysis labs
   - f/u Hct after 2 unit transfusion
   - get another peripheral IV
   - crossmatch 4 units
   - torso scan CT with contrast and head CT with contrast, to look for
   internal bleed site
   - guiac stool
   .
   # Hypotension: On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60. Question:
   sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus hypotension
   secondary to blood loss.
   - continue neo with goal MAP >60
   - continue vancomycin and zosyn
   - d/c flagyl as that would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and
   feel zosyn coverage for aspiration is adequate
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures)
   - f/u c.diff
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   - not weaning vent today due to tenuous status
   - Monitor PO2 and respiratory status
   - NPO
   - change oral meds to IV
   - f/u CXR read; CXR tomorrow
   - cont zosyn to cover for anaerobes
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Pressure support
   - Decreased Methadone to 5 to wean.  Continue at current dose for
   today.
   - Zyprexa PRN agitation
   - avoid sedation d/t AMS if possible
   - pm ABG
   .
     # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**].
   - Hold antihypertensives while on pressors, but have IV labetalol
   available for SBP >160 prn.
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: See hypotension section above.
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - f/u beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs
   - CT head with contrast today
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   - hold sedation
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR
   - Coumadin 5mg PO daily
   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   - if see any evidence for bleed on CT (given stable Hct in setting of 2
   transfusions pRBC), d/c heparin gtt (however continue it for now)
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD unstable.
   Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, s/p aspiration - NPO
   Prophylaxis: Heparin gtt, coumadin, sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: L art line which has been intermittently working and not
   working, may need to be replaced at some point. R PICC placed [**11-23**] now
   also reportedly not working, and may need to be pulled due to fevers,
   and if so, will need to have new central line placed. New L subclavian
   HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this line given
   how difficult it was to place. Consider placing a-line given on
   pressors today.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: pending rehab placement if can wean from vent.  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 273**]
   [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] working on placement. Place PT/OT consult.
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted to the ICU with dyspnea and acute renal failure. The patient's current condition is as follows:

- The patient is ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.
- He has been intermittently hypotensive and hypertensive, requiring pressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60.
- The patient has a fever of 101.4F, a rising white blood cell count, and a recent history of blood cultures.
- He has received multiple blood transfusions, with no significant rise in hemoglobin concentration.
- There is concern for intraabdominal bleeding, but no obvious visual signs of bleeding or oozing.
- The patient has altered mental status, with fluctuating levels of consciousness and agitation.
- He has a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) and has been on aspirin and statin therapy.
- The patient has been on heparin drip for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and is being bridged with warfarin.
- His renal function is acute on chronic, with unclear etiology.
- He has been on dialysis, but the CVVH has not been functioning well.
- The patient has a history of hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia due to renal failure.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes. 

The patient has been experiencing several medical complications, including fever, hypotension, anemia, respiratory failure, altered mental status, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The fever is likely due to an infection, possibly pneumonia or urinary tract infection, as indicated by the positive sputum culture showing Gram-negative rods and coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus. The hypotension may be caused by sepsis or blood transfusion reaction, but further evaluation is needed. The anemia is chronic and stable, possibly related to renal disease or autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). The respiratory failure may be secondary to aspiration pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The altered mental status is likely due to the PEA arrest and may be contributing to seizures, as indicated by the staring spells and epileptiform spikes on EEG. The DVT is a concern, especially with the presence of an inferior vena cava (IVC) thrombus.

The patient has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics (cefepime, vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, metronidazole), antihypertensives (labetalol), anticoagulants (heparin, coumadin), and dialysis (CVVH, HD). Additionally, the patient is on renal replacement therapy with peritoneal dialysis (PD) and has been prescribed medications such as epoetin-alpha (EPO) and Sevelemer.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, with multiple organ dysfunctions requiring careful management. It is important to address the ongoing infections, optimize glycemic control, manage blood pressure, and monitor for any further complications.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual who has been admitted to the ICU. They were previously on invasive ventilation but it was stopped. The patient has developed a fever of 101.4F and has been experiencing low blood pressure despite IV fluids. They are anuric on hemodialysis and have shown signs of improvement after being started on Neo. The patient's white blood cell count is increasing and gram-positive cocci have been found in their sputum. They have been started on vancomycin, zosyn, and flagyl.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, increasing white blood cell count, and hypotension despite IV fluids indicate a possible sepsis. This could be due to a respiratory or urinary source, or possibly an intra-abdominal infection.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning with acute respiratory failure. They were previously on CPAP/PSV mode but have been put back on PSV. There is a new opacity seen in their left apex on chest X-ray, suggesting a possible pneumonia or pulmonary embolism.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient is fluctuating between being somnolent and obtunded. This could be due to the underlying medical conditions or possibly related to sepsis.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient is anuric on hemodialysis, indicating a possible acute kidney injury. Further evaluation and management of renal

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units PRBC
   - General surgery consult for possible PEG placement as cause of liver
   hematoma
   - Consult IR regarding possible embolization for hepatic hematoma
   - trend Hct and coags q6h; transfuse as needed
   - get another peripheral IV
   - Active T&S; crossmatch 4 units
   - repeat PM CBC, DIC panel, hemolysis labs
   .
   # Hypotension: On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60. Question:
   sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus hypotension
   secondary to blood loss.  Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and
   clusters.
   - Continue neo with goal MAP >60
   - continue vancomycin and zosyn
   - d/c flagyl as that would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and
   feel zosyn coverage for aspiration is adequate
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures)
   -  c.diff negative
   - Hydrocort stress dose steroids
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.
   - not weaning vent today due to tenuous status
   - NPO
   - change oral meds to IV
   - f/u CXR final read
   - cont zosyn to cover for anaerobes
   .
   # Hyponatremia:  Check electrolytes post-dialysis
   .
   # Pain:  Patient clearly in pain and uncomfortable.
   - Morphine 1mg q4h prn
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Patient back on CMV/AC
   - Methadone 5mg; patient cannot get while NPO.
   - Zyprexa PRN agitation
   - avoid sedation d/t AMS if possible
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**].
   - Hold antihypertensives while on pressors, but have IV labetalol
   available for SBP >160 prn.
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: See hypotension section above.
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - f/u beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs
   - CT head with contrast today
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   - hold sedation
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR
   - Coumadin 5mg PO daily
   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   - if see any evidence for bleed on CT (given stable Hct in setting of 2
   transfusions pRBC), d/c heparin gtt (however continue it for now)
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD unstable.
   Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, s/p aspiration - NPO
   Prophylaxis: Heparin gtt, coumadin, sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now also reportedly not working, and may
   need to be pulled due to fevers, and if so, will need to have new
   central line placed. New L subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be
   very hesitant to pull this line given how difficult it was to place.
   Consider placing a-line given on pressors today.
   .
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure. He underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and was intubated due to possible hypoxia. The patient has a history of chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and chronic renal failure. He is currently ventilator-dependent and has altered mental status.

Medical Complications:
1. Liver hematoma: The patient has a liver hematoma that is causing difficulties in reversing the bleed. General surgery and interventional radiology (IR) consultations have been obtained for further management.
2. Hypotension: The patient has been intermittently hypotensive, with infectious source suspected. Antibiotics have been initiated, and the patient is being closely monitored.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin concentration has decreased significantly, and blood transfusions have been given. The cause of anemia is unclear, but it may be related to renal disease or acute blood loss.
4. Fever: The patient has had spiking fevers, which could be due to infection or a febrile transfusion reaction. Cultures have been obtained, and antibiotics have been adjusted accordingly.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal function has deteriorated, and he requires dialysis. His renal failure is acute on chronic, and he may not regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.
6. D

   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now

   .
   # Hct stable despite 2 units pRBC: DIC and hemolysis labs negative,
   consider bleed.  CT showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing
   bleed.
   - transfuse 2 units pRBC
   - repeat PM CBC, DIC panel, hemolysis labs
   - f/u Hct after 2 unit transfusion
   - get another peripheral IV
   - crossmatch 4 units
   - torso scan CT with contrast and head CT with contrast, to look for
   internal bleed site
   - guiac stool
   .
   # Hypotension: On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60. Question:
   sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus hypotension
   secondary to blood loss.  Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and
   clusters
   - continue neo with goal MAP >60
   - continue vancomycin and zosyn
   - d/c flagyl as that would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and
   feel zosyn coverage for aspiration is adequate
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures)
   -  c.diff negative
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   - not weaning vent today due to tenuous status
   - Monitor PO2 and respiratory status
   - NPO
   - change oral meds to IV
   - f/u CXR read; CXR tomorrow
   - cont zosyn to cover for anaerobes
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Pressure support
   - Decreased Methadone to 5 to wean.  Continue at current dose for
   today.
   - Zyprexa PRN agitation
   - avoid sedation d/t AMS if possible
   - pm ABG
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**].
   - Hold antihypertensives while on pressors, but have IV labetalol
   available for SBP >160 prn.
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: See hypotension section above.
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - f/u beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs
   - CT head with contrast today
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   - hold sedation
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR

   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   - if see any evidence for bleed on CT (given stable Hct in setting of 2
   transfusions pRBC), d/c heparin gtt (however continue it for now)
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD unstable.
   Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.

   Other less active/stable issues:

   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,

   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of

   - ISS

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He now requires mechanical ventilation due to altered mental status. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and chronic renal failure. He was previously on chronic hemodialysis (HD) and had a cardiac arrest.

Current issues:
1. Hypotension: The patient is intermittently hypotensive, with blood pressures ranging from 66 mmHg to 190/100 mmHg. It is unclear if the hypotension is due to an infectious source or volume loss. The patient is on neo and Labetalol to manage blood pressure.
2. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin concentration (Hct) is low at 19.6%. The anemia is likely related to chronic kidney disease (CKD) or blood loss. The patient has received two units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) but continues to have a declining Hct. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause of the anemia.
3. Fever and leukocytosis: The patient has had spiking fevers, suggesting an infection. Cultures have been obtained, and antibiotics have been started empirically. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, indicating a possible infection.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient requires mechanical ventilation due to severe hypoxia

   - Zyprexa PRN agitation
   - avoid sedation d/t AMS if possible
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**].
   - Hold antihypertensives while on pressors, but have IV labetalol
   available for SBP >160 prn.
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: See hypotension section above.
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - f/u beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs
   - CT head with contrast today
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   - hold sedation
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels including
   his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with coumadin
   - Daily INR
   - Coumadin 5mg PO daily
   - D/c heparin drip when has been therapeutic (INR between [**2-8**] for 24
   hours).  Ok to go to rehab on heparin drip.
   - if see any evidence for bleed on CT (given stable Hct in setting of 2
   transfusions pRBC), d/c heparin gtt (however continue it for now)
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD unstable.
   Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, s/p aspiration - NPO
   Prophylaxis: Heparin gtt, coumadin, sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now also reportedly not working, and may
   need to be pulled due to fevers, and if so, will need to have new
   central line placed. New L subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be
   very hesitant to pull this line given how difficult it was to place.
   Consider placing a-line given on pressors today.
   .
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: Family meeting regarding goals of care.  ICU care given
   acute developments.

Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of PEA arrest, hepatic hematoma, and respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving HD (likely meaning hemodialysis) and has had a large left hepatic hematoma discovered on a CT scan. The patient has received transfusions of 6 units of packed red blood cells and 1 unit of fresh frozen plasma overnight. The patient has allergies to vancomycin and has received multiple doses of antibiotics. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, has a history of anemia, and is experiencing hypotension, fever, hypertension, diarrhea, altered mental status, renal failure, and respiratory failure. The patient is also diagnosed with sepsis, acute blood loss anemia, DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation), sinus infection, subclinical seizures, thromboses, and CRF (chronic renal failure) requiring dialysis three times a week.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient is diagnosed with sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to infection causes injury to its own tissues and organs. This can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute Blood Loss Anemia: The patient has received a significant amount of blood transfusions, indicating a possible acute blood loss. This can result in anemia, which can compromise oxygen delivery to tissues and organs.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest, now ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC yesterday
   - Monitor coags and Hct q6h, transfuse for Hct <28; had stable hct
   yesterday, suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - Active T&S; crossmatch 4 units
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis.
   - Patient back on CMV/AC
   - pO2 on venous ABG 40; maintain current vent settings
   - Methadone 5mg; patient cannot get while NPO.
   - Consider Presedex to help calm agitation without depressing
   respiratory status
   - Zyprexa PRN agitation
   .
   # Fevers/Hypotension: On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.  Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs
   and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that would double-cover with zosyn for
   anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for aspiration is adequate.  C. diff
   negative.
   - Continue neo with goal MAP >60
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures)
   - Hydrocort stress dose steroids
   - Continue Bactrim until [**12-15**] for Stenotrophomonas
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt continues to be febrile following
   aspiration event.
   - not weaning vent today due to tenuous status
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes)
   - NPO while acute GI problems resolve
   - change oral meds to IV; not receiving Methadone
   .
   # Pain:  Patient clearly in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma.
   - Increase Morphine to 4mg q2h prn
   - Continue Versed 2-4mg q4h
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with
   coumadin.  All anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma discovered.
   - Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.
   - IV labetalol prn for SBP >160 prn.
   .
   # Spiking fevers, hypotension: See hypotension section above.
   Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with positive sputum
   Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U yesterday, hasn't
   received transfusions before this), possible drug reaction (started
   Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal perforation with
   free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG placed).   Currently
   afebrile.
   .
   Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx about 2
   wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added for
   purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of the
   CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.
   - Continue Bactrim until [**2107-12-15**]
   - Tylenol 650mg PO elixir q6hrs prn
   - [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future (febrile, and it
s an older line)
   and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to talk to IR about pulling the
   PICC, but holding for now given vascular complexity.
   - Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic reaction to blood
   transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still possible?
   - Continue Keppra for possibility of subclinical seizures causing
   fever, MS change --> discuss with Neuro
   - f/u beta-glucan and galactomannan
   - Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept and
   prednisone)
   - antibiotics and f/u cultures as above
   .
    # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 250 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Patient
   was interactive and following commands [**12-7**], significantly improved
   mental status compared to previous mornings.
   Today, less alert and interactive.
   - Continue Keppra 250mg IV q12h
   - f/u neuro recs
   - CT head with contrast today
   - extra 250mg IV keppra today
   - hold sedation
   - methadone 5mg TID to assist with weaning from narcotic dependence
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD MWF
   - Continue prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if HD unstable.
   Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid.
   - Started Sevelemer 30.
   .
   Other less active/stable issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # Hyponatremia:  Check electrolytes post-dialysis.  Resolved.
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachy and hypertensive.
   # HypoNa: Had been having issues with hyponatremia, but has since
   resolved.
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   # RUE swelling: Had u/s that did not completely visualize subclavian
   vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had PICC placed
   yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein with
   +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - ISS
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, s/p aspiration - NPO
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID)
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now also reportedly not working, and may
   need to be pulled due to fevers, and if so, will need to have new
   central line placed. L subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very
   hesitant to pull this line given how difficult it was to place.
   Consider placing a-line given on pressors today.
   .
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and subsequently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The patient is currently ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status.

The patient has several medical complications including hypotension, anemia, fever, respiratory failure, liver hematoma, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and chronic renal failure. He also has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and myocardial infarction (MI).

Assessment and plan:
1. Hypotension: The patient has been intermittently hypotensive, possibly due to infectious sources or blood loss. Sepsis and hypovolemia are being considered as potential causes. The patient is on neo (likely neosulfocystamine), a vasopressor, to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 60 mmHg. Continuing neo with goal MAP >60, and f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures) are recommended.
2. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, indicating anemia. Erythropoietin (EPO) will be given during hemodialysis (HD) to help stimulate red blood cell production.
3. Fever: The patient has had spiking fevers, possibly due to infection or transfusion reaction.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes. The patient has a history of chronic renal failure and is s/p continuous renal replacement therapy (CRT). He has been on dialysis three times a week.

The patient has had multiple complications, including a liver hematoma, which was not related to percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement, as determined by general surgery. The hematoma was managed conservatively with close monitoring of hematocrit (Hct) and coagulation parameters. The patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC) and was bridged with heparin due to venous thrombi in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC).

The patient's respiratory status has been unstable, with intermittent hypotension and hypertension. He was intubated during cardiac arrest and had evidence of aspiration, but the distinction between aspiration pneumonitis and pneumonia is unclear. He was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, and later switched to Bactrim as the fever trended down. The sputum culture revealed Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, which is sensitive to Bactrim.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He subsequently experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and is now ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status. The patient has multiple comorbidities including hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and chronic kidney disease. He is currently on multiple medications including hydrocortisone, morphine, midazolam, vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, Bactrim, and Keppra.

Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient has been intermittently hypotensive, which could be due to an infectious source or hypovolemia. He is currently on a neorodrenaline drip with a target mean arterial pressure (MAP) of >60 mmHg.
2. Fever: The patient has had recurrent fevers, which may be attributed to an infection or a febrile transfusion reaction. Further investigations are needed to determine the cause.
3. Liver Hematoma: The patient has a liver hematoma, likely secondary to a recent procedure. There is concern for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but laboratory results do not support this diagnosis. Monitoring of hematocrit (Hct) and coagulation parameters is ongoing, and transfusion is being considered to maintain an Hct >20%.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially required intubation for respiratory failure, which occurred in the setting of a cardiac arrest. There is some question about whether he has pneumonia or atelectasis, and cultures have revealed growth of Gram-negative rods and coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus.
5. Aspiration: The patient aspirated tube feeds, but the respiratory therapist and nurse were able to suction out the aspirate. There is concern for aspiration pneumonitis versus aspiration pneumonia. Antibiotics have been held until the patient shows signs of infection.
6. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has been found to have venous thrombi in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC). He is on a heparin drip and being bridged with warfarin. Anticoagulation was temporarily stopped due to the liver hematoma but has since been restarted.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease or acute blood loss. Erythropoietin (EPO) has been started at dialysis.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient had hyponatremia, which has since resolved.
9. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient had elevated potassium and phosphorus levels, likely secondary to renal failure. Alkaline hydroxide has been increased to 45 tablets per day.
10. Right Upper Extremity Swelling:

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 62-year-old male with multiple medical problems following a cardiac arrest. He has respiratory failure, ongoing fevers, and a large hepatic hematoma. The patient's altered mental status has worsened today. He is being treated with morphine and versed for pain control, and his respiratory failure is being managed with assisted ventilation. He is also on vancomycin and Zosyn for fevers and elevated white blood cell count, as well as Bactrim for stenotrophomonas. Thromboses are being prevented with heparin in the setting of the liver hematoma. The patient is undergoing hemodialysis for chronic renal failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure indicates an inability to adequately breathe on his own. This can lead to complications such as hypoxemia (low oxygen levels), hypercapnia (high carbon dioxide levels), and respiratory acidosis.
2. Renal Failure: The patient has chronic renal failure, which means his kidneys are not functioning properly. This can lead to electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and the buildup of waste products in the body.
3. Fever and Elevated White Blood Cell Count: The patient's ongoing fevers and elevated WBC count suggest an ongoing infection. If not treated promptly and effectively, this can lead to sepsis and septic shock.
