 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes) for a 7 day
   course, currently day 5 on [**12-16**], d/c on [**12-18**] -> will d/c today
   - Trach mask today as much as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - send another c.diff
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA as above
 can
   d/c today [**12-18**]
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures, aspergillus study)
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask planned for most of today, as tolerated
   - Pt has not received Fentanyl IV for >48 hours, will keep as prn but
   minimize use
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Continue Hydralazine Q6 hours; once BP stabilizes, consider
   transitioning to BP medication such as CCB or BB (hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) 239**]
   given acute on chronic renal failure) without the risk of rebound
   hypertension, given the patient
s history of labile BPs.
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   - start Atenolol 25mg Qday
   - Plan to dc hydralazine/labetolol ASAP
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, and abd much
   less tense than prior.  However, pt has had nausea with tube feeds and
   was only able to tolerate 2 hours of TF yesterday ([**12-17**]).
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Ok to restart tubefeeds but slowly
   - Will start Reglan 2.5mg TID standing for treatment of presumed
   diabetic gastroparesis
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - daily HCT
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.  Will follow up on results.
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Patient appears in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma and significant abdominal
   distension.  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed.  Initiated
   on Fentanyl IV.
   - Pt has not been receiving Fentanyl IV for >24 hours, and will
   minimize use for patient comfort
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, next HD [**2107-12-16**] (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 30.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi but will hold off on this discussion until
   next week, after the patient has been stable for another several days
   - consult heme-onc today for anti-coag recs
   .
   Less active issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Restarting tubefeeds today.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care continues given acuity of illness; discuss rehab
   placement with case management
Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), who experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis catheter.
- The patient has been ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.
- The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and coronary artery disease (CAD).
- The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2C, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 157/63 mmHg to 213/140 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
- The patient's physical examination reveals erythematous eyes, rales in the lungs, distended and tense abdomen, and pedal edema.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, liver enzymes, and lactate levels.
- Imaging studies reveal a large liver hematoma with perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the mesentery.
- The patient has been diagnosed with delirium, respiratory failure, aspiration pneumonia, liver hematoma, injected and irritated eyes, pain, acute on chronic renal failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), anemia, and transient ST elevations on EKG.
- The patient's medical complications include hypotension, hypertension, hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, right upper extremity swelling, and diabetic mellitus type II.
- The patient's ongoing management includes ongoing respiratory support, hemodialysis, antibiotic therapy, pain management, and anticoagulation therapy.
- The patient's family has been informed about the code status and discussed potential rehabilitation placement.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has been at risk for aspiration due to altered mental status and the use of a tracheostomy tube. This can lead to lung infection and worsening respiratory status.
2. Liver hematoma complications: The patient has a large liver hematoma, which can potentially lead to bleeding or further liver damage.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has evidence of venous thrombi in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC). If left untreated, this can lead to pulmonary embolism.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and there is a risk of further deterioration in kidney function.
5. Infection: The patient has been febrile at times, and there is a risk of developing sepsis or other infections.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient has had labile blood pressures, with episodes of hypotension and hypertension. This can lead to organ damage if not managed appropriately.
7. Delirium: The patient continues to have altered mental status, which can increase the risk of falls, self-extubation, and other complications associated with delirium.

   - overall, much improved mental status (patient talking, oriented and

 DELIRIUM / CONFUSION
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes) for a 7 day
   course, currently day 5 on [**12-16**], d/c on [**12-18**].
   - Trach mask today as much as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - send another c.diff
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA as above
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures, aspergillus study)
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask planned for most of today, as toelrated
   - Pt has not received Fentanyl IV for >24 hours, will keep as prn but
   minimize use
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Continue Hydralazine Q6 hours; once BP stabilizes, consider
   transitioning to BP medication such as CCB or BB (hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) 239**]
   given acute on chronic renal failure) without the risk of rebound
   hypertension, given the patient
s history of labile BPs.
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, but
   continued tense, distended, tympanitic abdomen.
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Ok to restart tubefeeds but slowly
   - f/u KUB from [**12-16**] final read
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - 3pm Hct today given drop
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.  Will follow up on results.
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Patient appears in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma and significant abdominal
   distension.  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed.  Initiated
   on Fentanyl IV.
   - Pt has not been receiving Fentanyl IV for >24 hours, and will
   minimize use for patient comfort
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, next HD [**2107-12-16**] (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 30.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi but will hold off on this discussion until
   next week, after the patient has been stable for another several days
   - Discuss with heme-onc on Monday [**12-19**]
   .
   Less active issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Restarting tubefeeds today.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care continues given acuity of illness.
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), who presented with dyspnea and acute respiratory failure. He underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) due to a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis catheter. The patient was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. He also has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic liver disease.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Respiratory status: The patient is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) mode, with improved mental status and respiratory effort. Tracheostomy tube in place.
- Hemodynamic monitoring: Blood pressure fluctuations, with recent hypertension. Labetalol has been initiated for blood pressure control.
- Fluid balance: Positive fluid balance due to ongoing diuresis.
- Temperature: Mild fever.
- Mental status: Agitated, disoriented, and not following commands. Previously, the patient had intact cognition and was conversant.
- Abdominal distension: Persistent and tympanitic abdomen, suggestive of chemical peritonitis. CT abdomen shows large liver hematoma and perihepatic hematoma.
- Liver function: Abnormal liver enzymes and coagulation profile, indicative of liver dysfunction.
- Renal function: Acute on chronic renal failure, with elevated creatinine and urea levels.
- Hematology: Elevated white blood cell count and platelet count.
- Coagulation: Abnormal coagulation profile, likely due to liver dysfunction.
- Neurology: Seizure-like activity detected on continuous EEG monitoring, for which Keppra has been started.
- Ophthalmology: Irritated eyes, for which eye drops have been recommended.
- Pain: Patient appears uncomfortable and in pain, likely due to stretch of the hepatic capsule and significant abdominal distension.
- Infection: Sputum cultures show growth of Gram-negative rods and coag-positive Staphylococcus. Aspiration event occurred, but no clear evidence of pneumonia on chest X-ray.
- Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Venous thrombi present in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC).
- Anemia: Chronic and stable, possibly related to renal disease or anemia of chronic disease.
- Hypercalcemia: Elevated serum calcium level, likely secondary or tertiary due to renal failure.
- Right upper extremity swelling: Resolved, with a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic vein detected during placement of the subclavian line.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with ongoing need for mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation.
2. Infection: The patient has shown signs of infection, with positive sputum cultures and fever. There is a risk of further infection, including hospital-acquired pneumonia and catheter-related bloodstream infection.
3. Liver hematoma: The patient has a large liver hematoma, which could lead to hemorrhagic complications if it ruptures.
4. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is deteriorating, with acute on chronic renal failure. There is a risk of worsening renal failure and the need for dialysis.
5. DVT: The presence of venous thrombi in multiple vessels increases the risk of pulmonary embolism (PE).
6. Hypercalcemia: Elevated serum calcium levels can lead to complications such as renal dysfunction, cardiac arrhythmias, and bone demineralization.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not appropriately managed, leading to fatigue, decreased oxygen carrying capacity, and other complications.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and seizure activity indicate a risk of ongoing neurological complications, including encephalopathy and further seizures.

Further evaluation and management are needed to address these potential complications and optimize the patient's care.

Summary:
The patient is a 62-year-old man with multiple problems post [**Name2 (NI) **] arrest, including respiratory failure, ongoing fevers/WBC, and large hepatic hematoma. The patient has been critically ill and is currently in the ICU.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Delirium/Confusion: The patient continues to be good today.
2. Respiratory Failure, Acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **]): The patient's respiratory failure is ongoing. TM as tolerated plus PMV.
3. Hepatic Hematoma/Blood Loss Anemia: Hct stable. Abd non-tender.
4. Hypertension: Will start standing beta blocker today.
5. Fevers and elevated WBC: Day [**3-19**] of Bactrim. Today is last day of vanc/zosyn. Flagyl day#4 --> will d/c after 3 c. diff negative.
6. Thromboses: Continue to hold heparin gtt in setting of liver hematoma.
7. CRF - HD per renal.
8. Remainder of issues per ICU team.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure needs to be closely monitored, and appropriate interventions should be taken to support his breathing.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**]. s/p 7-day course of vanc/zosyn for aspiration that
   ended on [**12-18**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Trach mask today as much as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - send another c.diff
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures, aspergillus studies)
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask planned for most of today, as tolerated
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Continue Hydralazine Q6 hours (wean this down once lisinopril starts
   acting)
   - Start lisinopril 10mg daily
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   - Increase atenolol to 50mg daily
   - Labetalol as a prn if SBP >160
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, and abd much
   less tense than prior.  However, pt has had nausea with tube feeds and
   was only able to tolerate 2 hours of TF yesterday ([**12-17**]).
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Encourage PO intake today
   - Continue Reglan 2.5mg TID standing for treatment of presumed diabetic
   gastroparesis
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - daily HCT
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.
   - f/u EEG read
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed and Fentanyl.
   - Pain controlled
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, HD today (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 800 tid.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi
   - consult heme-onc today for anti-coag recs
   .
   Less active issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, encourage PO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Hold tubefeeds. Speech & swallow consult.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place. Keep lines for now status
   quo.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care continues given acuity of illness; discuss rehab
   placement with case management today.
   ICU Care
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2107-11-23**] 06:22 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2107-11-30**] 04:57 PM

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of ESRD, HTN, DM, who was admitted with dyspnea and ARF. He has since developed respiratory failure, delirium, sepsis, liver hematoma, altered mental status, and multiple complications related to his medical conditions. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7C (99.9F), a heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 149/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and sinus rhythm. 

The patient's physical examination shows erythema in the eyes, rales in the lungs, distended abdomen with minimal improvement, and edema in the lower extremities. 

The patient's lab results indicate leukocytosis with a WBC count of 19.0, anemia with a Hct of 28.3, thrombocytopenia with a Plt of 112,000, and elevated liver enzymes. The sputum culture shows gram-negative rods and coag positive Staph aureus. 

The patient's assessment and plan include respiratory failure, delirium, sepsis, liver hematoma, altered mental status, and other less active issues such as anemia, DVT, endocrine disorders, and DM type II. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include aspiration pneumonia, ventilator-associated pneumonia,

   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn to cover for aspiration (anaerobes) for a 7 day
   course, currently day 5 on [**12-16**], d/c on [**12-18**] -> will d/c today
   - Trach mask today as much as tolerated
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - send another c.diff
   - Continue vancomycin/zosyn for presumed aspiration PNA as above
 can
   d/c today [**12-18**]
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   - f/u cultures (blood and sputum cultures, aspergillus study)
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask planned for most of today, as tolerated
   - Pt has not received Fentanyl IV for >48 hours, will keep as prn but
   minimize use
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Continue Hydralazine Q6 hours; once BP stabilizes, consider
   transitioning to BP medication such as CCB or BB (hold off on ACE/[**Last Name (un) 239**]
   given acute on chronic renal failure) without the risk of rebound
   hypertension, given the patient
s history of labile BPs.
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   - start Atenolol 25mg Qday
   - Plan to dc hydralazine/labetolol ASAP
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, and abd much
   less tense than prior.  However, pt has had nausea with tube feeds and
   was only able to tolerate 2 hours of TF yesterday ([**12-17**]).
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Ok to restart tubefeeds but slowly
   - Will start Reglan 2.5mg TID standing for treatment of presumed
   diabetic gastroparesis
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - daily HCT
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.  Will follow up on results.
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Patient appears in pain and uncomfortable, likely due to
   stretch of hepatic capsule due to hematoma and significant abdominal
   distension.  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed.  Initiated
   on Fentanyl IV.
   - Pt has not been receiving Fentanyl IV for >24 hours, and will
   minimize use for patient comfort
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, next HD [**2107-12-16**] (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 30.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi but will hold off on this discussion until
   next week, after the patient has been stable for another several days
   - consult heme-onc today for anti-coag recs
   .
   Less active issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Restarting tubefeeds today.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care continues given acuity of illness; discuss rehab
   placement with case management
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), and chronic hemodialysis (HD). He was admitted with dyspnea and acute respiratory failure (ARF), which progressed to ventilator dependency due to mental status changes. The patient also had aspiration during morning rounds and developed delirium/confusion. Other issues include injectable irritated eyes, pain, acute on chronic renal failure, hepatic hematoma, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), anemia, transient ST elevations on EKG, hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and right upper extremity (RUE) swelling. The patient's current condition is critical, and he is being managed in the intensive care unit (ICU).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial presentation was ARF, which has now progressed to ventilator dependency. There is a risk of further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or tracheostomy site infection.

2. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient had emesis during rounds and aspirated tube feeds. This increases the risk of aspiration pneumonia, which can lead to lung infection and sepsis.

3. Delirium/Confusion: The patient's mental status changes and delirium require close monitoring. There is a risk of worsening delirium or development of other psychiatric complications

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 62-year-old man with multiple medical problems post [**Name2 (NI) **] arrest, including respiratory failure, ongoing fevers/WBC, and large hepatic hematoma.
- The patient has been intubated and placed on invasive ventilation.
- He has been diagnosed with delirium/confusion, respiratory failure (not ARDS), hypertension, hepatic hematoma/blood loss anemia, altered mental status, and hypothyroidism.
- The patient has been started on antibiotics (Bactrim) and probiotics (Flagyl) due to fevers and elevated white blood cell count.
- Heparin has been held in the setting of liver hematoma, and the decision to restart anticoagulation will be made by hematology.
- The patient is on hemodialysis for chronic renal failure.
- Other issues are being managed by the ICU team.
- The patient is critically ill.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern. If not properly managed, it could lead to further deterioration in lung function and potentially result in pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Hepatic Hematoma: The presence of a large hepatic hematoma poses a risk of internal bleeding and potential hemorrhagic shock. Close monitoring and appropriate management are essential to prevent complications.

 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   61M with ESRD s/p CRT, HTN, DM, admitted with dyspnea and ARF and now
   s/p PEA arrest during IR placement of temporary HD catheter, now
   ventilator-dependent due to mental status.
   .
   # Aspiration:  Patient had emesis during morning rounds, aspirated tube
   feeds but respiratory therapist and nurse suctioned out aspirate.
   Currently not hypoxic and afebrile.  Risk for aspiration pneumonitis
   vs. aspiration PNA.  Hold on CXR until patient clinically shows signs
   of infection, as this would not change management currently.  Also hold
   antibiotics for now until patient shows evidence of aspiration
   pneumonia, but if signs of infection, consider Vanc/Cefepime/Flagyl.
   Patient on Vanc/Zosyn.  CXR shows no clear evidence of PNA but CT [**12-11**]
   showed confluent consolidative opacity of superior RLL, atelectasis vs.
   aspirationi or pneumonia.  Pt was febrile following aspiration event
   but is now afebrile on Vanc/Zosyn x 3 days.  However, sputum from [**12-13**]
   still growing Stenotrophomonas despite a course of Bactrim which
   finished [**12-15**]. s/p 7-day course of vanc/zosyn for aspiration that
   ended on [**12-18**].
   - Re-start Bactrim x14 day course, day 1=[**12-16**] to d/c [**12-30**]; appears
   Bactrim may not have been given at the correct times after HD and may
   have been dialyzed off in the past
   - Trach mask today
   .
   # Fevers: Infection (recent sputum with Micrococcus and now with
   positive sputum Cx's as well) vs blood transfusion reaction (got 1U
   yesterday, hasn't received transfusions before this), possible drug
   reaction (started Keppra recently) vs TTP (less likely) vs abdominal
   perforation with free air under diaphragm (although just had PEG
   placed).  Of note: has had a long course of Cefepime for a positive UCx
   about 2 wks ago with Pseudomonas and most recently Linezolid was added
   for purulent appearing CVL
s bilaterally that have been removed. One of
   the CVL
s grew out Micrococcus and according to ID, the Cefepime should
   have covered it. He received a 14d course of Cefepime and 9d course of
   Linezolid.   Sputum from [**12-2**] showed coag positive Staph aureus and
   Stenotrophomonas Maltophilia, both sparse growth, the latter of which
   is sensitive to Bactrim.  Fever curve down-trending on Bactrim, d/c
   Vanc/Zosyn.  Previously d/c
ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has
   gram (-) rods in sputum as well.  [**Month (only) 60**] need to pull PICC in the future
   (febrile, and it
s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to
   talk to IR about pulling the PICC, but holding for now given vascular
   complexity.  Normal haptoglobin reduces likelihood of hemolytic
   reaction to blood transfusion, but febrile transfusion rxn still
   possible?  Received inhaled pentamidine for prophylaxis (given cellcept
   and prednisone).  On neo since early this morning, goal MAP >60.
   Question: sepsis as etiology with fever and leukocytosis, versus
   hypotension secondary to blood loss.
   .
   Sputum shows GNR and GPC in pairs and clusters.  d/c
ed flagyl as that
   would double-cover with zosyn for anaerobes, and zosyn coverage for
   aspiration is adequate.  C. diff negative.  Continued profound
   increasing leukocytosis. Last elevated T on [**2107-12-12**] (101.9).
   Leukocytosis resolved following discontinuation of steroids.  Multiple
   C. diff toxins negative, will d/c Flagyl.  Afebrile.
   - Given elevated WBC count and long term abxs, have started empiric
   coverage for C. diff colitis.  Will also send C. diff toxin x 3 and
   will stop tx if all negative.  Despite multiple negative C. diff
   studies, will continue Flagyl as patient is clinically improving on his
   current antibiotic regimen and Flagyl may be treating an occult
   infection.
   - Continue Bactrim as above for Stenotrophomonas
   .
   # Labile blood pressures: Pt has been intermittently hypotensive
   (infectious source vs hypovolemia?) and hypertensive, for which he was
   getting Labetalol. He is now more persistently hypertensive, up to
   190
s/100
s.  Was transitioned from Labetalol drip to po Labetalol
   [**12-9**], then switched to Labetalol prn given fluctuating pressures.  On
   [**12-14**], Labetalol was d/c
ed and Hydralazine standing was started.
   - Decrease Hydralazine dose Q6 hours
   - Increase atenolol to 50mg daily
   - Continue lisinopril 10mg daily
   - Labetalol as a prn if SBP >160
   - Changed Hydrocort stress dose steroids to home Prednisone 5mg daily
   .
   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended
   and tympanitic, recent CT abdomen [**12-11**] showed large liver hematoma with
   scattered areas of perihepatic hematoma and scattered blood within the
   mesentery but without definite sites of active extravasation.
   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following
   reversal of anticoagulation vs. functional ileus/[**Last Name (un) **]
s syndrome
   from infection/sepsis, intra-abdominal bleed, narcotic use, or
   respiratory failure.  This is consistent with the patient
s continued
   +bowel sounds and leukocytosis, but CT abdomen did not show dilated R
   side of colon and loops of bowel were read to be wnl.  Currently
   improved abdominal pain and minimally improved distension, and abd much
   less tense than prior.  However, pt has had nausea with tube feeds and
   was only able to tolerate 2 hours of TF yesterday ([**12-17**]).
   - Monitor and manage conservatively for now, given patient
s underlying
   conditions are slowly resolving and he is clinically improving
   - Encourage PO intake today
   - Continue Reglan 2.5mg TID standing for treatment of presumed diabetic
   gastroparesis
   .
   # Liver Hematoma:  DIC and hemolysis labs negative, consider bleed.  CT
   showed hematoma of liver, difficulty reversing bleed.  s/p 2 units
   PRBC.  IR consulted re: possible embolization, did not feel the bleed
   was acute (felt >48 hours old) and wished to preserve hepatic artery
   and liver function if possible, so recommended monitoring Hct.  General
   surgery consulted re: possible relation to PEG placement, but did not
   believe this was [**2-7**] procedure based on the location of the hematoma.
   Recommended montoring q6h Hct and coags, transfusing as needed and
   keeping Hct >20.  Received 1 unit PRBC but has had stable Hct since,
   suggesting resolution of bleed with reversal of PTT/INR.
   - f/u Heme/Onc consult today for anti-coagulation for multiple thrombi
   in setting of recent liver hematoma
   - Monitor coags and Hct daily, goal Hct >28
   - Active T&S
   .
   Less Active Issues:
   .
   # Respiratory failure. Originally intubated in setting of arrest with
   possible hypoxia beforehand.  Some question of PNA on CT chest and has
   had CXR's with LLL atelectasis vs infiltrate, unclear whether he truly
   has PNA or not.  Had bronch that was unrevealing, Cx
s now reveal GNR
   and coag (+) staph.  Trach and PEG placed on [**12-2**].  Now off sedation,
   d/c
ed Seroquel, Propofol, Midazolam sedation.  On trach mask most of
   day with some resp acidosis. As of today ([**12-15**]), transitioned from AC
   to CPAP.
   - Trach mask today
   .
   # Altered mental status s/p PEA arrest:  Patient has intact brainstem
   reflexes but it is difficult to assess his cortex.  His MRI, though
   severely limited by motion artifact, did not show any signs of acute
   ischemia.  Weaning of sedation has consistently shown agitation. He was
   making some strides towards improvement last week, with following
   commands and responding to the environment, but most recently he has
   just been thrashing around and very agitated when sedation is weaned,
   not following commands, not tracking across the room, not making
   progress.  Changed from Propofol to versed because of triglycerides of
   700. Most recently, Neuro has noted a staring spell that was concerning
   for continued seizures, so he was on continuous EEG for a while, with
   epileptiform spikes but not outright seizure activity. They recommended
   a Keppra load, with Keppra 500 qday and an extra 250 after HD.  Today,
   the patient is not alert or interactive.  Neurology recommended 24 hour
   EEG monitoring, which was performed [**12-15**] with results pending.  On
   [**12-14**], the patient became significantly less agitated and was responsive
   and conversant, obeying commands and expressing intact cognition.
   Likely causes are delirium [**2-7**] medical condition and opioid withdrawal,
   and possible seizure and encephalopathy from acute liver failure or
   methadone use in the setting of liver failure.
   - Continue Keppra 500mg IV q12h; extra 250mg IV keppra with HD.
   - f/u neuro recs; Neuro re-consulted [**12-15**], completed 24 hour video EEG
   monitoring.
   - f/u EEG read
   .
   # Injected, Irritated Eyes:  Ophtho consulted, recommended eye drops.
   Improving.
   - Continue eye drops per Ophtho
   .
   # Pain:  Discontinued Morphine, Methadone, and Versed and Fentanyl.
   - Pain controlled
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure.  He is s/p CRT in [**2101**].  Etiology of
   ARF unclear thus far, but per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 699**] it is unlikely that he will
   regain enough renal function to be free of dialysis.  Had started back
   on CVVH after getting R groin HD line, but most recently this has not
   been functioning well, IR has tried to replace it, and had been
   unsuccessful. So, they placed a L subclavian line which has been
   working successfully.
   - f/u renal recs
   - HD per renal, HD today (MWF)
   - Continue home does of prednisone; may need stress dose prednisone if
   HD unstable. Change PO to IV steroids given NPO s/p aspiration.
   - On Renagel 800 tid, Sevelemer 800 tid.
   .
   # DVT: Patient found to have venous thrombi in several vessels
   including his IVC.  He was on a heparin drip, being bridged with
   coumadin.  However, all anticoagulation stopped when liver hematoma
   discovered.  Daily INR, no anticoagulation for now given liver hematoma
   and risk of bleed.
   - Will need to re-address the issue of anti-coagulation for the
   patient
s multiple thrombi
   - consult heme-onc today for anti-coag recs
   .
   Less active issues:
   .
   # Anemia.  See Hct section above.
   Previously, chronic and stable.  ?ACD (c/w recent Fe studies) vs.
   related to renal disease. B12 and Folate normal.  Doesn't appear to be
   DIC, or hemolysis.
   - EPO at HD
   .
   # ST elevations transiently seen on EKG: Transient, resolved; in
   setting of tachycardia and hypertensive.
   .
   # Endo: Elevated PTH is likely secondary or tertiary and due to renal
   failure. Has been hypercalcemic and hyperphosphatemic. Per renal recs,
   have increased AlOH to 45 tid.
   .
   # RUE swelling: Resolved. Had u/s that did not completely visualize
   subclavian vein, but was thought  that DVT was unlikely. When pt had
   PICC placed yesterday found a thrombosed/stenosed brachial-cephalic
   vein with +collaterals--needs plasty prior to Picc removal if afebrile.
   .
   # DM type II. Due to hypoglycemia surrounding cooling was taken off of
   long-acting insulin.  Glucose control suboptimal now w/ sliding scale
   only.
   - [**Hospital1 **] insulin
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, encourage PO, PMV use as tolerated.
   Hold tubefeeds. Speech & swallow consult.
   Prophylaxis:  sucralfate (per ID), pneumoboots
   Access: R PICC placed [**11-23**] now working, may need to be pulled due to
   fevers, and if so, will need to have new central line placed. L
   subclavian HD line placed [**11-30**], would be very hesitant to pull this
   line given how difficult it was to place. Keep lines for now status
   quo.
   Code:  Full (discussed with family)
   Communication: with wife [**Name (NI) 470**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10045**].
   Disposition: ICU care continues given acuity of illness; discuss rehab
   placement with case management today
   ICU Care

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis (HD) catheter and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.

The patient has a history of chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and chronic renal failure. He is currently on hemodialysis three times a week and has been on various antibiotics for suspected infections. The patient's recent course has been complicated by multiple issues, including respiratory failure, altered mental status, liver hematoma, DVT, and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, with periods of agitation and unresponsiveness. Seizure activity has been observed, but continuous EEG monitoring did not show any overt seizure activity. The patient is currently on keppra for seizure prophylaxis.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated due to hypoxia during CPR. He has had episodes of respiratory acidosis and has been on CPAP and tracheostomy. The patient's sputum cultures have revealed gram-negative rods and coag-positive staphylococcus. Further investigation is needed to determine if he has pneumonia or atelectasis.

3. Liver hematoma: The

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
- The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), hypertension, and diabetes mellitus.
- He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and is now ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.
- The patient has had multiple complications including aspiration, infection, liver hematoma, and renal failure.
- He has been on dialysis and has required multiple blood transfusions.
- The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure of 120/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%.
- His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and creatinine levels.
- The patient has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and anti-seizure medications.
- He has been on a heparin drip, bridged with coumadin, but all anticoagulation was stopped due to the discovery of a liver hematoma.
- The patient's pain is controlled, and he is being managed conservatively for abdominal distension.
- He has been advised to continue with renal replacement therapy and has been started on EPO at home.
- The patient's anemia is likely related to chronic renal disease or acute on chronic renal failure

Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute kidney injury (AKI). He has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease (CKD). The patient experienced an arrest during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis (HD) catheter and required mechanical ventilation. He is currently ventilator-dependent due to altered mental status.

The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, suspected aspiration pneumonia, infection with Micrococcus and Stenotrophomonas, liver hematoma, abdominal distension, labile blood pressure, foot pain, altered mental status, injected and irritated eyes, pain, acute on chronic renal failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), anemia, transient ST elevations on EKG, hyperparathyroidism, right upper extremity swelling, and type II diabetes mellitus.

The patient is on various medications including antibiotics (Vanc/Zosyn, Bactrim, Flagyl), anticoagulants (heparin, coumadin), anti-seizure medication (Keppra), and pain control medications.

Plan:
1. Video swallow to assess swallowing function and determine the safest and least restrictive oral diet.
2. Initiate oral intake of nectar thick liquids and soft solids with postural changes (PMV) for all oral intake.
3. Crush pills with puree.
4. Provide 1

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 62-year-old man with multiple problems following a [Name2 (NI)] arrest, including respiratory failure, ongoing fevers with an elevated white blood cell count, and a large hepatic hematoma. The patient's current condition and potential medical complications can be summarized as follows:

1. Hepatic Hematoma/Blood Loss Anemia: The patient has a large hepatic hematoma, which can lead to ongoing internal bleeding and subsequent anemia. Monitoring the patient's hemoglobin and hematocrit levels will be crucial to assess the severity of blood loss.

2. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, for which ACE inhibitors may be prescribed to help control blood pressure.

3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing acute respiratory failure, not associated with ARDS. Treatment includes maintaining the patient's oxygenation and ventilation parameters through therapies such as positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and mechanical ventilation.

4. Fevers and Elevated WBC: The patient has ongoing low-grade temperatures and an elevated white blood cell count, indicating an ongoing infection. Antibiotics have been administered, and further evaluation may be necessary to identify the source of infection.

5. Thromboses: The patient's thrombosis status is mentioned, but details are not provided. This suggests that there may be concerns about blood clots, and a consultation with hematology has been arranged.

6. CRF - HD per renal: The

ed cipro and linezolid and flagyl. Now has

s an older line) and replace with new CVL. [**Month (only) 60**] need to

ed flagyl as that

s/100

   # Abdominal Distension:  Patient
s abdomen continues to be distended

   Distension likely [**2-7**] chemical peritonitis which is resolving following

s syndrome

s continued

He was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF) and subsequently developed respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. The patient also experienced a perioperative cardiac arrest during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis catheter and was found to have multiple thrombi in several vessels, including the inferior vena cava (IVC).

The patient's current condition includes altered mental status, aspiration, fever, leukocytosis, liver hematoma, hypotension, hypertension, gout flare, abdominal distension, and anemia. He has been treated with various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, steroids, and renal replacement therapy.

The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, sepsis, liver hematoma, acute on chronic renal failure, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and possible drug reactions. He has been on renal replacement therapy and has had multiple central lines placed due to his condition.

Further management of the patient should include close monitoring of vital signs, respiratory status, and renal function. The patient's altered mental status requires ongoing assessment and management, including consideration of delirium, seizures, and encephalopathy. Summary:
The patient is a 61-year-old male with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) who was admitted with dyspnea and acute renal failure (ARF). He has a history of chronic renal failure, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. The patient underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) during the placement of a temporary hemodialysis (HD) catheter and was subsequently ventilator-dependent due to mental status changes.

The patient has been experiencing various complications, including aspiration pneumonia, sepsis, multi-drug resistant infections, liver hematoma, DVT, and anemia. He has undergone multiple interventions, such as tracheostomy, percutaneous gastrostomy (PEG), and placement of inferior vena cava (IVC) filter. The patient's condition has been unstable, with fluctuating blood pressures, altered mental status, and respiratory failure.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Aspiration: The patient had emesis during morning rounds and aspirated tube feeds. There is a risk for aspiration pneumonitis versus aspiration pneumonia. It is recommended to hold chest X-ray until the patient shows signs of infection, as this would not change management currently. Antibiotics will be held for now until the patient shows evidence of aspiration pneumonia, but if signs of infection are present, consider vancomycin, cefepime, and Flagyl.
2. Fevers: The patient's fever could be due to infection, blood
